column4: On the new ubuntu installer, when do I set the root password?
The root password is unset (therefore disabled) by default, for security reasons.
We would encourage you to use "sudo" when you need root functionality:)
That's pretty good I guess, but doesn't sudo have security risks?
Not sure myself, but I've read some things on it.
I think the idea for Ubuntu, is to stop users from running as root for their normal user.
root user is disabled, so you cannot ssh in as root, etc. etc.
Which leaves sudo as the only option to perform admin options. That's the way I see it anyway.
Yeah, that's good for the average joe who will never use ssh, but I like my advanced features.
If you do "sudo passwd", you can set the root password, which means you'll be able to login directly, or using su etc.
Yeah, and I'll probably remove sudo.
As Chousuke, you can use "sudo -s" to perform the same thing as "su". But, if you know plenty about Linux, you'd have already made up your mind about sudo vs su :)
Hehe fair enough, then you can use "sudo passwd" to re-enable it.
I run FreeBSD and gentoo systems, but just trying Ubuntu because it's the latest big thing.  Especially with LTS support etc.
Ah, nice to see the support having effect. You'll find Ubuntu "easier" than most other Linux/UNIX IMHO, if you stick with the way they want to do things
